summary: This is a digitally recorded sworn statement interview conducted by DOJ OIG Senior Special Agent with former BOP correctional officer . The interview is part of an OIG investigation into job performance and security failures related to the death of Jeffrey Epstein. The witness discusses his role as a lieutenant at MCC New York, policies regarding suicide watch and cellmate requirements, and the events surrounding Epstein being left without a cellmate on August 9-10, 2019.

keyFacts: The witness, a former BOP lieutenant, disputes a prior interview report that stated he knew Epstein's cellmate wasn't coming back and was waiting for the captain to assign a new one. He claims he only knew left for court, not that he was released.
Policy required that every shift, either the operations or activities lieutenant conduct rounds in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) with the inmates, not just sign paperwork.
Inmates on suicide watch or coming off suicide watch were required to have a cellmate at all times, and this was covered in both quarterly SHU training and annual refresher training.
The institution received a call at 1:50 p.m. on August 9, 2019, advising that inmate was not returning to MCC, leaving Epstein without a cellmate.

The witness believes Epstein's death was a suicide with no foul play, stating 'people just didn't do their job' and that multiple points of failure occurred in the communication chain regarding Epstein's cellmate status.
